title: 112_hr839
content: The Act may be cited as "The HAMP Termination Act of 2011". Congressional findings are also included. The Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) was designed to help financially struggling homeowners avoid foreclosure by modifying loans. However, as of February 2011, only 607,600 active permanent mortgage modifications were made under HAMP. Many homeowners whose HAMP modifications were canceled suffered because they made futile payments and some were forced into foreclosure. The Special Inspector General for TARP reported that HAMP benefits only a small portion of distressed homeowners and offers others little more than false hope. Terminating HAMP would save American taxpayers approximately $1.4 billion, as only $840 million has been disbursed out of the $30 billion obligated by the Department of the Treasury. The authority for HAMP is terminated, saving taxpayers $1.4 billion. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 terminates the authority to provide new assistance under the Home Affordable Modification Program, saving taxpayers $1.4 billion. The Home Affordable Modification Program's authority to offer assistance was terminated under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008, with unobligated funds being used for deficit reduction. The Secretary shall conduct a study on the use of the Home Affordable Modification Program by members of the armed forces, veterans, and gold star recipients. The Secretary will conduct a study on the usage and impact of the Home Affordable Modification Program for covered homeowners, and submit a report to Congress within 90 days. The term 'covered homeowner' refers to individuals eligible for mortgage assistance programs. The term 'covered homeowner' includes members of the Armed Forces, veterans, and Gold Star lapel pin recipients. Publication of member availability for assistance must be done within 5 days of enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must publish a statement on their website within 5 days of enactment, informing individuals about the termination of the Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) and advising them to contact their Member of Congress for assistance with negotiating a loan modification. Additionally, within 30 days of enactment, the Secretary must notify each individual who applied for HAMP. The Treasury will notify individuals who applied for the terminated Home Affordable Modification Program that the program has ended, loan modifications are no longer available, provide the contact information for their Member of Congress, and advise them to contact their Member of Congress for help in reaching their lender or servicer. The Treasury will notify individuals who applied for the terminated Home Affordable Modification Program that loan modifications are no longer available and provide contact information for their Member of Congress to help in reaching their lender or servicer for negotiating a loan modification. Congress encourages banks to provide loan modifications to eligible homeowners and assist with foreclosure prevention programs. Passed by the House of Representatives on March 29, 2011.
